title: Trump Administration Argues Law Doesn't Protect Gays From Workplace Bias
summary: Legal filing comes in highly anticipated case the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear in October. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Friday urged the Supreme Court to rule that a longstanding federal civil-rights law prohibiting sex discrimination doesn't protect gay people in the workplace.

title: Nissan and Carlos Ghosn Spar Over Yacht
summary: At auto maker's request, Caribbean court issues order preventing family from selling its yacht. A 120-foot yacht has become the latest bone of contention between Japanese auto maker Nissan Motor Co. and its former chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

title: Target, Facebook, Ford: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Resume Subscription. The bargain bin is back as shoppers seek out value and convenience. Discounter Target said sales at stores open at least a year rose 3.4% in the three months ended Aug. 3 while revenue and earnings also climbed. Its stock rose 20% Wednesday, the day its results were released. Target has been spending heavily to adjust to changes in shopping habits, and there were signs those improvements paid off. Digital sales were up 34% from a year earlier. Meanwhile, traditional department stores are still hurting; Nordstrom Inc. said that sales and profit slipped in the latest quarter.

title: Brazil's Leader Faces Pressure Over Amazon Fires
summary: Paris says it is opposed to a landmark trade deal the European Union reach with four South American nations. SÃO PAULO-Western leaders assailed Brazil's president over his stewardship of the Amazon rain forest, casting doubt on the future of a landmark trade deal between the European Union and South American nations.

title: Just Another Manic Friday
summary: Trump and Xi see who can take the most trade pain. Everyone loses.. The trouble with trade wars, like shooting wars, is that once they start you never know how they're going to end. The enemy gets a vote, and sometimes events escalate in ugly fashion. Take Friday, which saw China retaliate for Donald Trump's recent tariffs, Mr. Trump blow a gasket, markets tank, and Mr. Trump impose even more tariffs.

title: Illinois Death Could Be First Linked to Vaping
summary: Person who recently used an e-cigarette was hospitalized with severe respiratory illness and later died. An Illinois adult who developed a respiratory illness after using an electronic cigarette has died, state officials said on Friday, as more cases surfaced nationally of serious lung problems after vaping.

title: David Koch
summary: The free-market businessman lived up to his convictions.. When David Koch died Friday at age 79, the headlines underscored that he used his great wealth to "reshape" American politics.

title: The IMF Needs an Upgrade
summary: George Osborne or Mark Carney could be helpful in a global downturn.. When new British Prime Minister Boris Johnson spoke with Donald Trump recently, he had a specific request: Please support George Osborne, the former Chancellor of the Exchequer, to lead the International Monetary Fund. That's a favor Mr. Trump could do, and it might even make the fund relevant if the world economy runs into trouble.

title: India Leaves Risky Political Vacuum in Kashmir
summary: New Delhi didn't consult with local leaders before stripping the region of its semiautonomous status. SRINAGAR, India-India's decision to sideline Kashmiri political leaders as it enforces a military lockdown has left many locals wondering how their Muslim-majority state will mesh with an increasingly Hindu-dominant India.

title: Google Curbs Political Debate by Employees
summary: Company frowns on 'disrupting the workday to have a raging debate over politics'. Google issued new guidelines limiting employee discussion of politics and other topics not related to work, in a major shift for a company that has long prided itself on open debate and a freewheeling internal culture.

title: Qualcomm Taps Second Interim CFO This Year
summary: Wise to retire; Palkhiwala will fill role until permanent replacement is found. Qualcomm Inc. said Friday its interim finance chief David Wise is retiring.

title: Stocks, Bond Yields Fall on Trade Tensions
summary: Losses escalate after President Trump tweeted the U.S. 'would be far better off' without China. Stocks, government bond yields and commodities fell in a wild session Friday as anxieties over trade relations with China sparked fresh worries about global growth and the potential for a recession.

title: Trump Lashes Out at China, Sending Markets Falling
summary: Reacting to Beijing's announcement of more tariffs, president raises U.S. tariffs, says 'we don't need China' and takes fresh aim at Fed's Jerome Powell. President Trump said he "hereby ordered" U.S. companies doing business in China to explore relocating their operations and stiffened tariffs on Chinese imports after Beijing unveiled its own new levies on American goods, the latest twists in a trade war rattling investors and confounding central bankers.

title: Obama Still Can't Build That
summary: Bureaucrats, community organizers strike back against former President's plan to develop historic park.. Before making commitments to environmental "stakeholders" who have no stake in his business, perhaps JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon should have observed the resistance mounted by local stakeholders in Chicago to the planned Obama Presidential Center. On the other hand, Mr. Dimon will likely never try to build a bank branch in the middle of a public park.

title: Despite Safeguards, Fentanyl Trade Is Still a Problem
summary: Trump's tweet puts spotlight on long-running efforts to combat sales of synthetic opioid. President Trump's tweet Friday ordering delivery companies to block shipments of fentanyl from China put a spotlight on long-running efforts to combat trafficking of the deadly synthetic opioid.

title: Book Publishers Sue Amazon's Audible to Block Coming Audiobook Captioning Service
summary: Audible Captions will let users see lines of machine-generated text as they listen to audiobooks, a step publishers say violates copyright law. Seven U.S. publishers have filed a lawsuit against Audible, Amazon.com Inc.'s audiobook subscription service, alleging its plan to offer real-time captioning of some audiobook titles violates copyright law.

summary: Supreme Court says Justice Ginsburg completed three-week course of treatment. WASHINGTON-Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg completed a three-week course of radiation for a malignant tumor on her pancreas, which was "treated definitively," the court said on Friday.

title: Farmers Brace for Diminished Harvest
summary: Tensions run high as Farm Belt deals with weak crop and more trade tensions. Corn and soybean production will fall sharply this year as a result of harsh weather, a closely watched trade publication said, adding to worsening financial pressure that is heightening tensions across the Farm Belt.

title: Free Podcasts Are Good for Me but Bad for Business
summary: Listeners are awash in free content, but podcasters face likely trouble ahead if the growing industry stays hooked on ad revenue. Wondery Inc. podcast network's "Business Wars," Guy Raz's "How I Built This" and Phoebe Judge's "Criminal" top my playlist.

title: Fed's Clarida Shrugs Off Market Drop, Offers Little Guidance on Rates
summary: In a TV interview, the central bank's No. 2 official says he is upbeat on the economy. The Fed's second-in-command shrugged off heavy stock-market losses in a television interview Friday and affirmed his positive view on the economy, in comments that offered little guidance on what he would like to see with monetary policy over coming months.

title: South Korea Feels the Trade War Burn
summary: South Korean exporters are caught in the crossfire of U.S.-China tensions and a dispute with Japan. South Korean stocks are among the world's worst performers this year, as its export-focused companies grapple with not one, but two trade fights and slowing global growth.

title: U.S. Aims to Block Sale of Ukraine's Aerospace Company to China
summary: Washington objects to pending sale of Motor Sich on national-security grounds. WASHINGTON-U.S. national-security adviser John Bolton is seeking to scuttle the pending Chinese acquisition of a Ukrainian aerospace company on grounds that it will give Beijing vital defense technology, according to senior U.S. administration officials familiar with the matter.

title: Democrats Tweak 'Medicare for All' Pitches Amid Resistance From Unions
summary: Concern that workers could lose generous benefits spurs new messaging by some 2020 candidates. DAVENPORT, Iowa-Democratic presidential candidates supporting a bigger government role in health care are stepping up appeals to union members-a key constituency-who are concerned that a proposed expansion of Medicare would leave them with less-generous benefits than they now enjoy.

title: Starbucks Supplier Delivery Workers Vote to Authorize Strike
summary: Union members at warehouses covering distribution to Starbucks stores across the Midwest rejected a proposed contract, the Teamsters union says. Unionized workers at a supplier to hundreds of Starbucks Corp. coffee shops in Chicago and other Midwestern cities rejected a proposed contract agreement and voted to authorize a strike, the Teamsters said Friday.

title: La-Z-Boy Shares Aren't Taking a Break
summary: Furniture company's stock is a rare winner as broader market tumbles. In a stumbling market, La-Z-Boy Inc. shares are energized.

title: Powell Issues Warning Over Trade, Signals More Rate Cuts Are Possible
summary: Trump fires back on Twitter after central bank chairman says China tensions are stoking anxieties. JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell gave his most forceful warning yet about the risks to the U.S. economy from escalating trade tensions and the limits to the central bank's ability to cushion any fallout.

title: Judge in Chicago Appoints Former U.S. Attorney to Investigate Jussie Smollett Case
summary: Dan Webb to review prosecutor's handling of case in which actor allegedly faked hate crime against himself. CHICAGO-A Cook County judge on Friday named former U.S. Attorney Dan Webb as a special prosecutor to re-examine the case against Jussie Smollett, the actor accused of faking a hate crime against himself.

title: U.S. Treasury Prices Climb Amid Trade Turmoil
summary: Yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury note falls to lowest level since August 2016. U.S. government bond prices surged on Friday, pushing the yield on the 10-year Treasury note to a multiyear low as investors flocked to safer assets in response to a further escalation of the U.S.-China trade conflict.

title: The Robots Are Coming (to Judge Gymnastics)
summary: The international gymnastics federation may add new technology in time for the 2020 Olympics-and pave the way for artificial intelligence in judged sports. The international gymnastics federation has voted on whether to expand the use of sophisticated new technology in major upcoming competitions, a move that could ultimately shift control over the sport's judging from humans to robots.

title: Oil Slides as Latest China Tariffs Reignite Demand Fears
summary: Some analysts fear latest tariffs will further slow global economy. Oil prices fell Friday after China said it would impose tariffs on $75 billion worth of additional U.S. products including crude imports and President Trump said he would respond, the latest trade developments that investors fear could crimp fuel consumption.

title: BOE's Carney Floats Idea of New, Virtual Reserve Currency
summary: Such a synthetic currency potentially could damp dollar dominance, ease burden of greenback's moves on smaller economies. LONDON-Central banks should consider joining forces to create a virtual currency that could supplant the dollar's role in the global economy, Bank of England Gov. Mark Carney said, offering a novel solution to concerns about the greenback's status as the world's foremost reserve currency.

title: Explosion of Space Shuttle Tested CEO of Morton Thiokol
summary: Charles Locke headed maker of rocket boosters blamed for Challenger disaster. Nothing in Charles Locke's career prepared him for the public role thrust upon him when the space shuttle Challenger exploded shortly after launch on Jan. 28, 1986.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Freezes Antitrust Ruling Against Qualcomm
summary: Court allows chip maker to continue current business practices for now, in a setback for the FTC. A federal appeals court froze a ruling that Qualcomm Inc. had committed an array of antitrust violations, a boost for the chip maker that allows it to maintain its business practices for the time being.

title: Deutsche Bank to Pay $16 Million for Improper Hiring Practices
summary: Bank agreed to settle Foreign Corrupt Practices Act charges by the SEC related to the hiring of relatives of foreign government officials. Deutsche Bank AG has agreed to pay $16 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it violated U.S. foreign bribery law by hiring relatives of foreign government officials.

title: New York City Has Been Releasing Burial Records of Fetal Remains-and Names of Women Linked to Them
summary: Medical ethicists say publishing such information on Hart Island cemetery is an invasion of privacy that could cause harm. For nearly a decade, New York City has made public the names of thousands of women who had either miscarriages, stillbirths or possibly abortions between 1981 and 2017, raising alarms among medical privacy experts.

title: Sinclair Eyes More Regional Sports Networks as Disney Deal Closes
summary: CEO Chris Ripley said properties Sinclair is interested in include four AT&T-owned regional sports outlets. Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc.'s appetite for regional sports networks won't be satiated with its $9.6 billion purchase of Walt Disney Co. 's 21 channels, which closed Friday after getting the green light from the Justice Department.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Form Human Chains in Latest Opposition Tactic
summary: Thousands of people of all ages and backgrounds link hands for miles in a pledge of solidarity. Hong Kong protesters embarked on a new and peaceful way to get their message across to the world.

title: Ex-Trump Affiliate Secretly Worked for Years With Prosecutors, FBI and CIA
summary: Russian-born businessman Felix Sater 'went above and beyond' in cooperating after facing fraud charges in 1998, unsealed letter shows. A Russian-born businessman at the center of a plan to build a Trump-branded tower in Moscow spied for U.S. law-enforcement and intelligence agencies, providing cooperation at a "breadth rarely seen" against mobsters and others in matters unrelated to the president, federal prosecutors wrote in a newly unsealed letter.

title: France Investigates Jeffrey Epstein
summary: Prosecutors aim to determine if French underage girls were among victims of the New York financier. PARIS-French prosecutors, acting on information about alleged rape of underage French girls, have launched a preliminary investigation to determine whether the Jeffrey Epstein scandal had ramifications in the country.

title: Amazon Deal Opens Door to Bigger Footprint in India
summary: Future Retail investment could give e-commerce giant access to physical stores across India. MUMBAI- Amazon.com Inc. is acquiring a small stake in one of India's largest retailers in a deal that gives it an option to take a much larger stake after three years, underlining its interest in expanding its operations in Asia's third-largest economy.

title: Court Filings Shed New Light on Arrest of Huawei Executive
summary: Meng Wanzhou was detained by immigration authorities in Vancouver for some three hours before she was informed of her arrest. Meng Wanzhou was detained by immigration officials in Vancouver shortly after stepping off a Cathay Pacific plane with a companion last Dec. 1 and questioned for three hours before being told she was being arrested.

title: What Do We Do About Violent Young Men?
summary: As a guardian ad litem, I dealt with severely disturbed, violent boys. These boys invariably were from fractured families without any involvement by their fathers.. In "Violent Young Men, Here and Abroad" (op-ed, Aug. 14), Reuel Marc Gerecht brings a note of honesty to the "gun violence" debate where, despite the rhetoric, few really believe that a land awash with guns can simply legislate gun violence away. No one would say that Juárez, Mexico, with its draconian gun-control laws and its 1,247 homicides last year is safer than El Paso, Texas, with its lax gun-control laws and its record of 23 homicides.

title: Bad Design on 737 MAX Had a Terrible Cost
summary: After the extensive accident investigations, there is no doubt that the malfunction of the new MCAS computer in the 737 MAX is the probable cause of two terrible crashes.. After the extensive accident investigations, there is no doubt that the malfunction of the new MCAS computer in the 737 MAX is the probable cause of two terrible crashes ("The 4-Second Catastrophe: Why Boeing's MAX Failed," Page One, Aug. 17). However, focusing on assigning blame for the crashes to Boeing or the FAA is diverting attention from a significant contributory cause of the accidents-crew training in developing countries. The crews failed to respond to the manifestation of a runaway stabilizer by simply turning it off, which is a memory item. The primary rule in aviation is maintaining aircraft control, and then analyzing the situation and taking proper action. Not addressing this issue out of sensitivity will do absolutely nothing to enhance flight safety and prevent a recurrence under a different component failure.

title: Trump Divides the U.S., but He Isn't Alone
summary: Silly me for believing that racial divisiveness has been firmly embedded in the dominant culture since our nation's inception.. Heather Mac Donald lays the current state of divisiveness, with its alarming uptick in hate crimes and mass shootings, squarely at the feet of "Democratic elites," concluding that "the primary responsibility rests with its main propagators: the academic left and its imitators in politics and mass media" ("Trump Isn't the One Dividing Us by Race," op-ed, Aug. 19). Really?

title: Fed's Warning: We Can't Solve Everything
summary: As China tensions mount and President Trump fumes, Fed chairman reminds world of limits to monetary policy. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell probably wishes his job was as easy as not talking about the elephant in the room.

title: U.K. Regulator Warns Claims-Management Firms About Misleading Advertising
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority said it would take action against companies that fail to identify themselves or disclose fees in marketing materials. A U.K. financial regulator on Friday issued a warning to claims-management companies, saying the industry has been providing misleading information to customers in its marketing materials.

title: Kayaking the Los Angeles River, an Improbable Eden
summary: A paddling tour on the L.A. River is surprisingly challenging and bucolic-and best followed by riverside margaritas. It felt like I was in a rain forest in Borneo. A strong current swept my kayak straight into a dense bamboo grove, where fronds wrapped themselves around my arms and ground my progress to a halt. As I untangled myself, a gleaming fish leapt from the water and a white egret took flight, as if mocking my predicament. But this wasn't a remote tropical tributary, or even a lost corner of the Everglades. In fact, minutes earlier I had been sitting in heavy traffic on a Los Angeles freeway. I was only a few miles east of Hollywood on a stretch of the Los Angeles River, where kayaking on summer weekends has become the city's hottest new excursion into an exciting alternative reality: Nature.

title: Papers Outline Increased Fed Focus on Global Factors and Communication
summary: Academic research highlights how the global financial crisis has reshaped central banking. JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.-Two papers presented at the Kansas City Fed's policy symposium on Friday offered recommendations for central bankers to improve policy-making during a period of increased economic uncertainty.

title: A River Runs Through Where?
summary: Paddling up the Los Angeles River. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Divided G-7 Leaders Headed for Clashes at Tense Summit
summary: Club of rich nations is divided on how to deal with nearly every issue they are set to discuss at Biarritz gathering. Once a showcase for international cooperation, Group of Seven summits have turned into minefields of geopolitical discord-and this year's gathering promises another feast of high-level squabbling.

title: When Modernism Came to Mexico
summary: A new show spotlights six women who helped to make the country a center of cosmopolitan, forward-thinking art.. When Clara Porset arrived in Mexico in 1935, she was already a successful furniture designer in her native Cuba. Strongly influenced by European modernism, Porset believed that design could elevate the experience of daily life. She envisioned a homegrown modernism, international in outlook but with a uniquely Mexican perspective. And Mexico-undergoing its own rapid modernization-was receptive ground for her ideas.

title: Brexit Bargain Shoppers: Investors Snap Up Peppa Pig, Beer and Jet Technology
summary: Foreigners have acquired U.K.-listed companies as a weak British pound makes valuations more attractive. While many investors are nervous about Brexit, others appear to see bargains, judging by a string of major acquisitions by foreigners of U.K.-listed companies.

title: A Stellar Lament of Lost Love
summary: Hoagy Carmichael's 'Star Dust,' with lyrics by Mitchell Parish, is probably the most-recorded American song in history..

title: Best Choices for Summer Grilling
summary: Labor Day tip: These mail-order sausages are sustainably made and doggone delicious. IT'S NOT ALWAYS easy being a meat eater, particularly if you want to do it ethically. And yet Brent Young, owner of the butcher shop the Meat Hook in Brooklyn, N.Y., makes it sound pretty simple. "It comes down to land use and soil health," he said. The Meat Hook sources pork for its mail-order sausage company, launched last spring, from Gibson Farm, an operation that occupies a little under a square mile in Valley Falls, N.Y., using what's known as regenerative agriculture. On the Meat Hook Sausage Co. website, that's defined as "the theory that animals, when managed properly, can be used as a tool to regenerate soil, promote plant growth [and] reverse erosion, desertification, and ultimately climate change."

title: Ukraine Gets a Church of Its Own, and Putin Glowers
summary: As Moscow tries to keep ex-Soviet republics under its sway, a move by the Eastern Orthodox church has plunged Russia and Ukraine into a contest for Ukrainians' religious loyalties. When the patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church consecrated the first stone of what is planned to be a towering green-and-gold cathedral outside Moscow last fall, Vladimir Putin and his defense minister were front and center for the ceremony. The Russian president even pledged some of his own money to fund the cathedral's centerpiece icon.

title: Not All Energy Stocks Are Depressed
summary: Shares of smaller, lower-cost Diamondback Energy remain higher in 2019. The topsy-turvy oil market has battered most energy companies, but there is one diamond in the rough.

title: Mexican Economy Stagnated in Second Quarter
summary: Economic output has slowed sharply on weakness in investment and industrial output. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's economic activity was flat in the second quarter as a modest increase in services offset declines in industrial output and agricultural production.

title: 'Wackadoodle': A Ludicrous Word for Ludicrous Times
summary: A suddenly current term mixes the aggressive sound of a blow with the comic barnyard cry of a rooster. On Monday, after President Trump tweeted the unfounded assertion that Google had somehow "manipulated" millions of votes in favor of Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election, CNN chief legal analyst Jeffrey Toobinsaid, "In a day of wackadoodle claims, this is the most wackadoodle of all, because there is not even any claim that Google manipulated votes." He added, "No one claims that except Donald Trump."

title: Aegerion Creditors Approve Drugmaker's Chapter 11 Plan
summary: Bankrupt pharmaceutical company's chapter 11 plan hands control of assets to Amryt Pharma. Creditors of Aegerion Pharmaceuticals Inc. have approved a bankruptcy plan that hands the cholesterol drugmaker's business to Dublin-based Amryt Pharma PLC.

title: Israel Strikes Iraq in Expansion of Campaign Against Iran
summary: The hit on a weapons cache north of Baghdad marks the latest effort to contain Tehran. Israel recently struck a weapons depot in Iraq it believed Iran was using to move weapons to Syria, expanding its campaign to target Tehran's military presence in the Middle East, a U.S. official said.

title: Investigators Warned Other Companies After Norsk Hydro Attack
summary: Aluminum producer shared more information than usual with authorities, helping identify other targets, prosecutor says. Norwegian authorities were able to learn enough about the hackers behind the March cyberattack on Norsk Hydro AS A to warn other companies and prevent similar attacks, officials said.

title: 'The Borgias' and 'The Family Medici' Review: Dangerous Dynasties
summary: New histories of both families, by talented historians who 'know how to make the past come alive without turning it into pulp.'. Readers of history, like all readers, love an engrossing narrative: a conquest triumphant or repulsed, a great man brought to ruin by his flaws. The story doesn't have to have heroes and villains, but it doesn't hurt.

title: Nebraska Court Approves Keystone XL Pipeline
summary: Decision to uphold state regulator's OK resolves key dispute, but hurdles remain. The Nebraska Supreme Court upheld the state's approval of the Keystone XL pipeline Friday, but hurdles to the long-delayed project remain.

title: Facebook's Secondhand Shopping Problem
summary: Facebook needs Marketplace to work, but it shouldn't be in a rush. Facebook says it is a changed company, but recent problems suggest it is still struggling to enforce its own rules on its platforms.

title: The Next Cycle of Jonathan Vaughters's Life
summary: The American ex-pro cyclist has become a team manager-and the former doper has turned antidoping activist. The Tour de France was over, and Jonathan Vaughters-the American former cyclist, current team manager and doper turned antidoping activist-had one more stop to make.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Severe water shortage in India, casualties of the U.S.-China trade conflict, measuring day at the London Zoo, glut of luxury ranches in the Midwest and more..

title: 'Cold Warriors' Review: The War of Words
summary: There was a saying during World War II: 'Books Are Weapons in the War of Ideas.' During the Cold War, writers east and west doubled down on that sentiment.. My diary for Dec. 10, 1982, has me in Paris attending a "noisy, spirited" conference of Polish dissidents. A year after Gen. Jaruzelski's suppression of Solidarity, and a few weeks into Andropov's rule of the Soviet Union, writers like Leszek Kolakowski and Konstanty Jeleński were debating the best way forward for supporters of democracy and for Warsaw's timid archbishop, Józef Glemp. I had been brought to the Polish Library on the Quai d'Orléans by the novelist Mary McCarthy, my friend and mentor, recently turned 70, whom the diary describes as being that day "full of schoolgirlish enthusiasm . . . She likes to applaud and say bravo and wave and shake hands with all she recognizes."

title: Children's Books: Back to School, With Excitement and Trepidation
summary: Young girls and boys, a bear cub, a pet tortoise-and Mo Willems's well-known pigeon-head to school in picture books for young readers making the same transition.. When you are small, what is "school," exactly? You don't know, but you hear things: It's a place where children learn (however that's supposed to work) and eat from lunch boxes and make new friends and sit crisscross-applesauce during circle time. To hear adults talk, there's nothing to fear. So why, when you are small, can the prospect of entering this garden of delights be so nerve-racking?

title: 'Casting Into the Light' Review: A Poetics for Surfcasters
summary: As a novice surfcaster on Martha's Vineyard, Janet Messineo sought the wisdom of aloof island ﬁshermen who did not suffer women gladly.. Janet Messineo remembers the beauty of the first striped bass she ever caught, one day off a jetty on Martha's Vineyard. "Dark blue-black lateral stripes ran down the length of its olive-green back," she writes in "Casting Into the Light: Tales of a Fishing Life." "The scales on the belly were shiny silver with subtle iridescent reds and purples. I gave thanks to the heavens, then joined the others back on the jetty."

title: Five Best: Aaron Shulman on Literary Lives
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'The Age of Disenchantments.'. By Tom Reiss (2005)

title: 'The Mosquito' Review: Humanity's Six-Legged Enemy
summary: Mosquitoes and the diseases they carry have plagued armies from Athens to Yorktown.. It's an ambitious book that aims to deliver a tour of Western military history from antiquity to the jungles of Vietnam-and an account of how one tiny arthropod repeatedly molded that history, thwarting generals, sickening peasants and popes, and killing billions of people. Timothy C. Winegard has pulled off this feat in his enthusiastic if imperfect "The Mosquito: A Human History of Our Deadliest Predator."

title: The Apple Card: Leave Home Without It
summary: The new credit card is shiny, beautiful, and apparently better off left at home. The Apple Card has arrived.

title: 'The Vinyl Frontier' Review: Greetings From Planet Earth
summary: The Voyager spacecraft carried a gold-plated LP-a mixtape for aliens ﬁlled with Bach, Chuck Berry, Javanese gamelan music and more.. In the 1970s Age of Aquarius, seizing on a rare alignment of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune, NASA hatched a plan to slingshot a pair of spacecraft around a succession of planets and off into interstellar space. Like robot paparazzi on hopped-up Vespas, Voyager 1 and 2 would shoot photos and beam back data all the way. They would also-in a spirit of peace, love and abounding trust-carry a message to the universe.

title: 'The Doomsday Calculation' Review: How Much Time Do We Have Left?
summary: Don't worry. Scientists can predict with 95% confidence that the world won't end before 2031.. Armageddon comes in many guises: climate breakdown, asteroid strike, zombie apocalypse. But just as interesting a question as what might cause the world to end is the question of when it might cease to exist. According to some scientists, we can make confident predictions about the latter by using a simple probability theorem, with some estimates anticipating our demise in as little as 12 years. Just how worried should we be? Or is it all just a geeks' parlor game?

title: Fiction: The Foolish Heart of a World-Spirit
summary: A German master evokes Goethe's late-lifeobsession with a 19-year-old girl.. At the spry age of 72, the German writer and humanist Johann Wolfgang von Goethe became infatuated with 17-year-old Ulrike von Levetzow, a fixation that inspired his poem "The Marienbad Elegy" and now serves as the model for Martin Walser's novel "A Man in Love" (Arcade, 283 pages, $25.99), translated by David Dollenmayer. In his day, Goethe was the most famous person in Germany; Ulrike was a fatherless teenager with no protection from the storms of gossip and opprobrium. Goethe's interest in her ought to make for a creepy, proto-#MeToo cautionary tale. How, then, has Mr. Walser spun such a sweet and affecting story from it?

title: 'The Memory Police' Review: Daring to Remember
summary: In a feat of dark imagination, Yoko Ogawa stages an intimate, suspenseful drama of courage and endurance while conjuring up a world that is at once recognizable and profoundly strange.. 'The Memory Police," by Yoko Ogawa, published in Japan in 1994 and now translated into English by Stephen Snyder, opens with a timeless, affecting scene in which a mother shares with her young daughter (the novel's narrator) some treasured memories and mementos-a ribbon, a bell, a jewel, a postage stamp-while preparing the child for a future of losses. "You'll see for yourself," the mother explains, "something will disappear from your life." The prediction is a chilling understatement. For on this family's island home, all sorts of things-birds, roses, maps-have for years been vanishing overnight and simultaneously fading from most people's memories. (The child's mother, crucially, is one of a dwindling minority whose recall is undiminished.)

title: Mysteries: Justice in the Eye of the Storm

title: The Joy of Clutter: What Marie Kondo Got Wrong
summary: We're in danger of Marie Kondo-ing our way to empty lives. An artful pile of meaningful objects can be richly autobiographical. But you need a good eye-or these tips from design pros. I AM AN UNABASHED magpie; tchotchkes dot the hill I will die on. They're mostly vacation mementos, like the silver, Victorian, mussel-shaped "match safe" that I splurged on in a Rome antique shop with my newly minted fiancé. I keep other dust-collectors at hand for a reason. My husband and I are trying to eliminate most of our screen time at home, and having books and playing cards within reach makes it much easier to resist our phones. Besides, the cards are beautiful and graphic.

title: All Those Adages of Geniuses Are a Big Scam
summary: If Albert Einstein can be wrong, how many other famous sayings are just waiting to be disproved?. On July 3, I defied Albert Einstein's famous declaration that the definition of insanity is to repeatedly do the same thing but expect a different result. I once again tried to lose weight by carrying around a little pocket diary to count calories. I'd tried this method five years straight and always ended up with the same result: I tipped the scales at 210.6 pounds when I started, and I tipped the scales at around 210.6 pounds when I finished. Sometimes 211.4. Sometimes 213.2.

title: The Way Music Affects Our Lives
summary: The art and practice of music has touched the the lives of these six columnists, from a symphony director to a Turner Prize-winning artist.. "It used to be that I couldn't leave the house without my headphones on, but now I really appreciate silence. For me it's more interesting when I'm pulling mu- sic apart and it becomes more elemental. Music is composed, it's sound arranged into melody and harmony, so I'm in- terested in deconstructing it. It can become sculptural and define the space you're in. You might sing a really well- known pop song, but when you strip it back to just the voice and leave spaces for instrumenta-tion, it can become something completely different through gaps and silences. There's that Emily Dickinson quote where she mentions a boy who sings to himself by the grave to keep himself company because he's afraid. When I use my voice in my work, I want to evoke a sense of solitude. And I find the songs you sing when you're alone are melancholy songs."
